Initial comments:This report is the result of an onsite special monitoring investigation completed on September 28, 2023, at Wilkes-Barre General Hospital related to the discontinuation of planned inpatient pediatric services and removal of 12 pediatric beds. This will decrease the bed count from 381 to 369.  It was determined that the facility was in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 PA Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998. Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of an onsite special monitoring investigation completed on September 28, 2023, at Wilkes-Barre General Hospital related to the discontinuation of planned inpatient pediatric services and removal of 12 pediatric beds. This will decrease the bed count from 381 to 369.  It was determined that the facility was in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 PA Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998. Plan of Correction:

Initial comments:This report is the result of an unannounced onsite investigation (PA 66462) completed on September 27-28, 2023, at Wilkes-Barre General Hospital. It was determined that the facility was not in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 PA Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998. Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of an unannounced onsite investigation (PA 66462) completed on September 27-28, 2023, at Wilkes-Barre General Hospital. It was determined that the facility was not in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 PA Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998. Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of an unannounced onsite investigation (PA66462) completed on September 27-28, 2023, at Wilkes-Barre General Hospital. It was determined the facility was not in compliance with the requirements of 42 CFR, Title 42, Part 482-Conditions of Participation for Hospitals. 482.13 Condition of Participation: Patient Rights The facility failed to ensure a patient that was on 15 liters of oxygen via a non-rebreather mask via a portable oxygen tank who had an ultrasound completed in the radiology department was monitored by staff after being placed in the radiology holding area awaiting transport back to the nursing unit. The Immediate Jeopardy Template was provided to the facility on September 27, 2023, at 1230. The survey team identified an Immediate Jeopardy regarding tag A0144: the patient has the right to receive care in a safe setting. The facility submitted an Immediate Jeopardy Abatement Plan at approximately 2:55 PM. The plan was accepted. The abatement plan included the following:The facility's Chief Executive Officer, Chief Nursing Officer, and Chief Quality Officer created a radiology policy in consultation with the Director of Radiology and the Chief, Radiology Section outlining the expectation that all emergency and inpatients having imaging studies will be supervised by hospital staff trained in basic life support at all times, until return to their patient room. Immediate education, in the form of read and sign, on the new policy was implemented immediately to include all clinical staff with direct patient care responsibilities ex: radiology, transportation, and nursing. On September 27, 2023, the survey team interviewed the facility's Administrative and Executive staff, reviewed the new radiology policy, conducted observational rounds of the radiology and nursing units and interviewed staff in these areas, and reviewed the immediate education that was provided to staff to determine compliance for the removal of the immediate jeopardy. The Immediate Jeopardy was abated on September 27, 2023, at 4:30 PM.  Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of an unannounced onsite investigation (PA66462) completed on September 27-28, 2023, at Wilkes-Barre General Hospital. It was determined the facility was not in compliance with the requirements of 42 CFR, Title 42, Part 482-Conditions of Participation for Hospitals. 482.13 Condition of Participation: Patient Rights The facility failed to ensure a patient that was on 15 liters of oxygen via a non-rebreather mask via a portable oxygen tank who had an ultrasound completed in the radiology department was monitored by staff after being placed in the radiology holding area awaiting transport back to the nursing unit. Immediate education, in the form of read and sign, on the new policy was implemented immediately to include all clinical staff with direct patient care responsibilities ex: radiology, transportation, and nursing. On September 27, 2023, the survey team interviewed the facility's Administrative and Executive staff, reviewed the new radiology policy, conducted observational rounds of the radiology and nursing units and interviewed staff in these areas, and reviewed the immediate education that was provided to staff to determine compliance for the removal of the immediate jeopardy. The Immediate Jeopardy was abated on September 27, 2023, at 4:30 PM.  Plan of Correction: 482.13 CONDITION PATIENT RIGHTS:A hospital must protect and promote each patient's rights.Observations:Based on the seriousness of the non-compliance and the effect on patient outcome, the facility failed to substantially comply with this condition.The facility failed to ensure a patient that was on 15 liters of oxygen via a non-rebreather mask via a portable oxygen tank and transferred to radiology to have an ultrasound completed was monitored by staff after being placed in the radiology holding area awaiting transport back to the nursing unit. A discussion took place with EMP1, EMP2, and EMP3 regarding the survey team's concerns related to the Patient Rights on September 27, 2023, at 1230.Cross reference482.13 (c)(2) Patient Rights: Care in Safe Setting  Plan of Correction - To be completed: 11/12/2023The facility's executive team including the Chief Executive Officer, Chief Nursing Officer, and Chief Quality Officer reviewed the immediate jeopardy findings and led the development of the plans to address the same.  The facility's Chief Executive Officer, Chief Nursing Officer, and Chief Quality Officer created a radiology policy in consultation with the Director of Radiology and the Chief, Radiology Section outlining the expectation that all emergency and inpatients having imaging studies will be supervised by hospital staff trained in basic life support at all times, until returning to their patient room. Immediate education, in the form of read and sign, on the new policy was implemented immediately to include all clinical staff with direct  patient care responsibilities ex: radiology, transportation, and nursing.  Direct observation rounding began immediately and is being performed by the Radiology director or designee, theChief Nursing Officer, the nursingsupervisor, and Chief Quality Officer toensure compliance with the new policy.All failures to adhere to the policy will be reviewed. A monthly report of the results of the audits will be presented to the Patient Safety Committee on a monthly basis until compliance is 100%for three consecutive months. 482.13 CONDITION PATIENT RIGHTS: A hospital must protect and promote each patient's rights. The facility's Chief Executive Officer, Chief Nursing Officer, and Chief Quality Officer created a radiology policy in consultation with the Director of Radiology and the Chief, Radiology Section outlining the expectation that all emergency and inpatients having imaging studies will be supervised by hospital staff trained in basic life support at all times, until returning to their patient room. Immediate education, in the form of read and sign, on the new policy was implemented immediately to include all clinical staff with direct  patient care responsibilities ex: radiology, transportation, and nursing.  Direct observation rounding began immediately and is being performed by the Radiology director or designee, theChief Nursing Officer, the nursingsupervisor, and Chief Quality Officer toensure compliance with the new policy.All failures to adhere to the policy will be reviewed. A monthly report of the results of the audits will be presented to the Patient Safety Committee on a monthly basis until compliance is 100%for three consecutive months. 482.23(c)(1), (c)(1)(i) & (c)(2) STANDARD ADMINISTRATION OF DRUGS:(1) Drugs and biologicals must be prepared and administered in accordance with Federal and State laws, the orders of the practitioner or practitioners responsible for the patient's care as specified under §482.12(c), and accepted standards of practice.(i) Drugs and biologicals may be prepared and administered on the orders of other practitioners not specified under §482.12(c) only if such practitioners are acting in accordance with State law, including scope of practice laws, hospital policies, and medical staff bylaws, rules, and regulations.(2) All drugs and biologicals must be administered by, or under supervision of, nursing or other personnel in accordance with Federal and State laws and regulations, including applicable licensing requirements, and in accordance with the approved medical staff policies and procedures.Observations:Based on review of facility documents, staff interview (EMP), and review of medical records (MR), it was determined the facility failed to ensure a physician order was received for a patient that was placed on Airvo (high flow oxygen) and failed to ensure a physician order was received to titrate oxygen on a patient for one of one medical record reviewed (MR1).Findings include:Review on September 28, 2023, of facility policy, "High Flow Nasal Cannula," reviewed January 2023, revealed  "Purpose 1. To deliver heated humidified high flow oxygen up to 60 L / m using a nasal cannulae, mask, trach mask, or t-piece. 2. To deliver humidified high flow oxygen at 100 relative humidity from 35 degrees Celsius to 37 degrees Celsius without discomfort to the patient or damage to the airway. A specific FIO2 can be delivered when using a blender. Policy 1. High flow oxygen devices will be used with patients who are unable to maintain adequate oxygen saturation using conventional oxygen delivery systems before using CPAP / BIPAP or mechanical ventilation.  ...Procedure (Set Up And Delivery) 1. Verify physician order.  ...Airvo2 1. Policy Statement Heated High Flow oxygen is a humidifier with an integrated flow generator that delivers warmed respiratory gases at optimal levels to spontaneously breathing patients through a variety of patient interfaces.  ...6. Procedure A. Physician order must be entered in the EMR for High Flow Oxygen Therapy.  ...7. Prepare the Airvo2 unit...K. Titrate Fio2 per physician order."  Review on September 28, 2023, of MR1, revealed the patient was admitted to the facility on September 20, 2023, with a non-ST elevation (NSTEMI). Further documentation revealed MR1 was placed on Airvo on September 22, 2023, at 0855. There was no order for Airvo. Interview with EMP5 on September 28, 2023, at approximately 1230, confirmed the findings noted above for MR1. EMP5 confirmed there was no physician order for Airvo. Continued review of MR1 on September 27, 2023, revealed nursing documentation dated September 24, 2023, at 1854 revealed MR1 was sent to ultrasound on non-rebreather on 15 L of oxygen. The patient's O2 saturation was 93-94%. Verified with respiratory therapist in regards to patient oxygen requirements for transport. The patient was awake and alert. The patient was transferred to a litter by this RN and coworker, as well as transport. The patient was transported to ultrasound. This RN was called that patient was in v-fib (irregular heart rate) on heart monitor. Ultrasound did not answer the phone. This RN went to the ultrasound department and found the patient on the litter in the waiting area. The non-rebreather was deflated, and the oxygen tank was empty. This RN checked for a pulse; the patient was pulseless and not breathing. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) was immediately started. A Code blue called overhead. The team arrived and began all resuscitation efforts. Further documentation revealed MR1 expired on September 24, 2023, at 1604. Interview with EMP1 on September 27, 2023, at approximately 1100, confirmed the findings noted above for MR1. Interview with EMP5 on September 28, 2023, at approximately 1300, confirmed there was no physician order to titrate oxygen on MR1 from Airvo to 15 L to transport to ultrasound.  Plan of Correction - To be completed: 11/12/2023The Chief Nursing Officer is ultimately responsible for the implementation of the plan of correction and the monitoring of the same.The facility's Chief Executive Officer,Chief Nursing Officer and Chief QualityOfficer created a radiology policy inconsultation with the Director ofRadiology and the Chief, RadiologySection outlining the expectation that all emergency and inpatients havingimaging studies will be supervised byhospital staff trained in basic lifesupport at all times, including in theholding area, until return to their patient room.  Immediate education, in the form of a read and sign, on the new policy was implemented to include all clinical staff with direct patient care responsibilities ex: radiology, transportation and nursing.Direct observation rounding will beimmediately performed by theRadiology director or designee, theChief Nursing Officer, the nursingsupervisor, and Chief Quality Officer toensure compliance with the new policy.All failures to adhere to the policy will be reviewed. A monthly report of the results of the audits will be presented to the Patient Safety Committee on a monthly basis until compliance is 100% for three consecutive months.The facility's Chief Nursing Officer, Chief Quality Officer and Respiratory Therapy Director reviewed the Oxygen Therapy Protocol Policy and High Flow Nasal Cannula Policy on October 6, 2023 to discuss changes to the policies.  The oxygen therapy protocol policy was adjusted to reflect the inclusion of nursing to further clarify the process relating to oxygen therapy titration and adjustment for transportation.  The pulmonary section approved the changes on Monday, October 9, 2023 and forwarded to the Medical Executive Committee (MEC) for approval.  The MEC approved the changes on October 10, 2023.  The MEC requested the information technology department add the oxygen protocol to any oxygen order entered by providers at the facility as a part of the order facilitating the enacting of the protocol as intended per the policy. The nursing and respiratory therapy staff will be educated on the policy changes and changes to the oxygen orders, with an emphasis on validating orders from providers, via read and sign no later than November 12, 2023 or before the start of their next work shift if after November 12, 2023.  The medical staff will be educated on the changes to the oxygen orders reflecting the oxygen protocol as per MEC request no later than November 12, 2023 via read receipt of an email memo. Weekly audits of medical records will be performed by the Respiratory Therapy director or designee, the Chief Nursing Officer, the nursing supervisor, and Chief Quality Officer to ensure compliance with the policy. All failures to adhere to the policy will be reviewed and addressed through re-education or the disciplinary process as appropriate.  A report of the results of the audits will be presented to the Patient Safety Committee on a monthly basis until compliance is 100% for three consecutive months.  All data reported in the Patient Safety Committee is also reviewed at the Medical Executive Committee and by the Board of Trustees. 482.23(c)(1), (c)(1)(i) & (c)(2) STANDARD ADMINISTRATION OF DRUGS: (1) Drugs and biologicals must be prepared and administered in accordance with Federal and State laws, the orders of the practitioner or practitioners responsible for the patient's care as specified under §482.12(c), and accepted standards of practice.(i) Drugs and biologicals may be prepared and administered on the orders of other practitioners not specified under §482.12(c) only if such practitioners are acting in accordance with State law, including scope of practice laws, hospital policies, and medical staff bylaws, rules, and regulations.(2) All drugs and biologicals must be administered by, or under supervision of, nursing or other personnel in accordance with Federal and State laws and regulations, including applicable licensing requirements, and in accordance with the approved medical staff policies and procedures. All data reported in the Patient Safety Committee is also reviewed at the Medical Executive Committee and by the Board of Trustees. 482.13(c)(2) STANDARD PATIENT RIGHTS: CARE IN SAFE SETTING:The patient has the right to receive care in a safe setting.Observations:Based on review of facility documents, staff interview, and review of a medical record (MR1), it was determined the facility failed to ensure a patient that was on 15 liters of oxygen via a non-rebreather mask via a portable oxygen tank and transferred to radiology to have an ultrasound procedure was monitored by staff after being placed in the radiology holding area awaiting transport back to the nursing unit for one of one medical record reviewed (MR1).Findings include:Review on September 27, 2023, of facility policy, "Patient's Bill of Rights," revised April 23, 2023, revealed "Purpose: The purpose of this policy is to delineate the Patient's Bill of Rights. Policy: We recognize your rights as a patient, and we support your participation in the health care decisions that affect your well being.  ...You have the right to:  ...An environment that is safe ...."  A request was made to the facility for a policy/procedure related to monitoring a patient that is on 15 liters of oxygen via a non-rebreather mask via a portable oxygen tank in the radiology holding area awaiting transport back to the nursing unit. None was provided.Interview with EMP1 on September 27, 2023, at approximately 1115, revealed there was no policy related to monitoring a patient that is on 15 liters of oxygen via a non-rebreather mask via a portable oxygen tank in the radiology holding area awaiting transport back to the nursing unit.Review on September 27, 2023, of MR1 revealed the patient was admitted to the facility on September 20, 2023, with a non-ST elevation (NSTEMI). A routine ultrasound retroperitoneal kidney was ordered on September 23, 2023. Nursing documentation by EMP17 dated September 24, 2023, at 1854 revealed MR1 was sent to ultrasound on a non-rebreather on 15 liters of oxygen. The patient oxygen saturation was 93-94%. The patient was awake and alert. The patient was transferred to a litter by this RN and coworker as well as transport. The patient was transported to ultrasound. This RN was called that the patient was in v-fib (irregular heart rate) on a heart monitor. Ultrasound did not answer the phone. This RN went to the ultrasound department and found the patient on the litter in the waiting area. The non-rebreather was deflated, and the oxygen tank was empty. This RN checked for a pulse; the patient was pulseless and not breathing. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) was immediately started. A Code blue was called overhead. The team arrived and began all resuscitation efforts. Further documentation revealed MR1 expired on September 24, 2023, at 1604. Interview on September 27, 2023, with EMP1 confirmed the findings noted above for MR1. Review on September 24, 2023, of the facility Event Log from September 24, 2023, revealed an Event Report dated September 24, 2023, for MR1 that revealed MR1 was placed in the holding area after completion of the ultrasound and the oxygen was still working. As the employee was completing a scan on another patient, they heard a page from the floor and then a code in radiology. Interview on September 27, 2023, with EMP1 confirmed the above findings. EMP1 confirmed MR1 was placed in the radiology holding area after the renal ultrasound was completed.  The patient was not monitored by staff.  Plan of Correction - To be completed: 11/12/2023The Chief Nursing Officer is ultimately responsible for the implementation of the plan of correction and the monitoring of the same. The facility's Chief Executive Officer,Chief Nursing Officer and Chief QualityOfficer created a radiology policy inconsultation with the Director ofRadiology and the Chief, RadiologySection outlining the expectation that all emergency and inpatients havingimaging studies will be supervised byhospital staff trained in basic lifesupport at all times, including in theholding area, until return to their patient room. Policy: We recognize your rights as a patient, and we support your participation in the health care decisions that affect your well being.  ...You have the right to:  ...An environment that is safe ...."  A request was made to the facility for a policy/procedure related to monitoring a patient that is on 15 liters of oxygen via a non-rebreather mask via a portable oxygen tank in the radiology holding area awaiting transport back to the nursing unit. None was provided.Interview with EMP1 on September 27, 2023, at approximately 1115, revealed there was no policy related to monitoring a patient that is on 15 liters of oxygen via a non-rebreather mask via a portable oxygen tank in the radiology holding area awaiting transport back to the nursing unit.Review on September 27, 2023, of MR1 revealed the patient was admitted to the facility on September 20, 2023, with a non-ST elevation (NSTEMI). A routine ultrasound retroperitoneal kidney was ordered on September 23, 2023. Nursing documentation by EMP17 dated September 24, 2023, at 1854 revealed MR1 was sent to ultrasound on a non-rebreather on 15 liters of oxygen. The patient oxygen saturation was 93-94%. Review on September 24, 2023, of the facility Event Log from September 24, 2023, revealed an Event Report dated September 24, 2023, for MR1 that revealed MR1 was placed in the holding area after completion of the ultrasound and the oxygen was still working. 107.61-107.65 of this title.Observations:Based on review of facility documents, staff interview (EMP), and review of medical records (MR), it was determined the facility failed to ensure a physician order was received for a patient that was placed on Airvo (high flow oxygen) and failed to ensure a physician order was received to titrate oxygen on a patient for one of one medical record reviewed (MR1).Findings include:Review on September 28, 2023, of facility policy, "Optio-Flow High Flow Nasal Cannula,"  reviewed January 2023, revealed  "Purpose 1. To deliver heated humidified high flow oxygen up to 60 L / m using a nasal cannulae, mask, trach mask, or t-piece. 2. To deliver humidified high flow oxygen at 100 relative humidity from 35 degrees Celsius to 37 degrees Celsius without discomfort to the patient or damage to the airway. A specific FIO2 can be delivered when using a blender. Policy 1. High flow oxygen devices will be used with patients who are unable to maintain adequate oxygen saturation using conventional oxygen delivery systems before using CPAP / BIPAP or mechanical ventilation.  ...Procedure (Set Up And Delivery) 1. Verify physician order.  ...Airvo2 1. Policy Statement Heated High Flow oxygen is a humidifier with an integrated flow generator that delivers warmed respiratory gases at optimal levels to spontaneously breathing patients through a variety of patient interfaces.  ...6. Procedure A. Physician order must be entered in the EMR for High Flow Oxygen Therapy.  ...7. Prepare the Airvo2 unit  ...K. Titrate Fio2 per physician order."  Review on September 28, 2023, of MR1, revealed the patient was admitted to the facility on September 20, 2023, with a non-ST elevation (NSTEMI). Further documentation revealed MR1 was placed on Airvo on September 22, 2023, at 0855. There was no order for Airvo. Interview with EMP5 on September 28, 2023, at approximately 1230, confirmed the findings noted above for MR1. EMP5 confirmed there was no physician order for Airvo. Continued review of MR1 on September 27, 2023, revealed nursing documentation dated September 24, 2023, at 1854 revealed MR1 was sent to ultrasound on a non-rebreather on 15 L of oxygen. The patient's O2 saturation was 93-94%. Verified with respiratory therapist in regards to patient oxygen requirements for transport. The patient was awake and alert. The patient was transferred to the litter by this RN and coworker, as well as transport. The patient was transported to ultrasound. This RN was called that the patient was in v-fib (irregular heart rate) on heart monitor. Ultrasound did not answer the phone. This RN went to the ultrasound department and found the patient on the litter in the waiting area. The non-rebreather was deflated, and the oxygen tank was empty. This RN checked for a pulse; the patient was pulseless and not breathing. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) was immediately started. A Code blue called overhead. The team arrived and began all resuscitation efforts. Further documentation revealed MR1 expired on September 24, 2023, at 1604. Interview with EMP1 on September 27, 2023, at approximately 1100, confirmed the findings noted above for MR1. Interview with EMP5 on September 28, 2023, at approximately 1300, confirmed there was no physician order to titrate oxygen on MR1 from Airvo to 15 L to transport to ultrasound.  Plan of Correction - To be completed: 11/12/2023The Chief Nursing Officer is ultimately responsible for the implementation of the plan of correction and the monitoring of the same.The facility's Chief Executive Officer,Chief Nursing Officer and Chief QualityOfficer created a radiology policy inconsultation with the Director ofRadiology and the Chief, RadiologySection outlining the expectation that all emergency and inpatients havingimaging studies will be supervised byhospital staff trained in basic lifesupport at all times, including in theholding area, until return to their patient room. Immediate education, in the form of a read and sign, on the new policy was implemented to include all clinical staff with direct patient care responsibilities ex: radiology, transportation and nursing.Direct observation rounding will beimmediately performed by theRadiology director or designee, theChief Nursing Officer, the nursingsupervisor, and Chief Quality Officer toensure compliance with the new policy.All failures to adhere to the policy will be reviewed. A monthly report of the results of the audits will be presented to the Patient Safety Committee on a monthly basis until compliance is 100% for three consecutive months.The facility's Chief Nursing Officer, Chief Quality Officer and Respiratory Therapy Director reviewed the Oxygen Therapy Protocol Policy and High Flow Nasal Cannula Policy on October 6, 2023 to discuss changes to the policies. The oxygen therapy protocol policy was adjusted to reflect the inclusion of nursing to further clarify the process relating to oxygen therapy titration and adjustment for transportation. The pulmonary section approved the changes on Monday, October 9, 2023 and forwarded to the Medical Executive Committee (MEC) for approval. The MEC approved the changes on October 10, 2023. The MEC requested the information technology department add the oxygen protocol to any oxygen order entered by providers at the facility as a part of the order facilitating the enacting of the protocol as intended per the policy.The nursing and respiratory therapy staff will be educated on the policy changes and changes to the oxygen orders, with an emphasis on validating orders from providers, via read and sign no later than November 12, 2023 or before the start of their next work shift if after November 12, 2023. The medical staff will be educated on the changes to the oxygen orders reflecting the oxygen protocol as per MEC request no later than November 12, 2023 via read receipt of an email memo.Weekly audits of medical records will be performed by the Respiratory Therapy director or designee, the Chief Nursing Officer, the nursing supervisor, and Chief Quality Officer to ensure compliance with the policy. All failures to adhere to the policy will be reviewed and addressed through re-education or the disciplinary process as appropriate. A report of the results of the audits will be presented to the Patient Safety Committee on a monthly basis until compliance is 100% for three consecutive months. Initial comments:This report is the result of an unannounced onsite special monitoring investigation completed on January 13, 2023, at Wilkes-Barre General Hospital. It was determined that the facility was not in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 PA Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998. Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of an unannounced onsite special monitoring investigation completed on January 13, 2023, at Wilkes-Barre General Hospital. It was determined that the facility was not in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 PA Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998. Plan of Correction: 117.26 (b)(1-4) LICENSURE PHYSICIAN ON-CALL SCHEDULE:117.26 (b) Acceptable methods of providing 
medical coverage for the emergency 
service include the following:  (1) Use of house staff under 
adequate medical staff supervision.  (2) Rotating panels of staff 
physicians.  (3) Contractors whose members 
may or may not be members of the 
medical staff.  (4) Physician hospital 
employes.Observations:Based on review of facility documents, medical records (MR) and staff interview (EMP), it was determined the facility failed to ensure cardiothoracic surgery on-call services, interventional radiology on-call services, and vascular surgery on-call services were provided for the Emergency Department (ED). Findings include:Review on January 13, 2023, of the facility's "Wilkes Barre General Hospital Medical Staff Bylaws," dated adopted and approved April 22, 2021, revealed  "... 2.2 Responsibilities The responsibilities of the Medical Staff include:  ... 2.2(b) Accounting for the quality, appropriateness and cost effectiveness of patient care rendered by all practitioners and AHPs authorized to practice in the Hospital, by taking action to: (1) Assist the Board and CEO and their designees in data compilation, medical record administration, review and evaluation of cost effectiveness and other such functions necessary to meet accreditation and licensure standards, as well as federal and state law requirements;  ..."Review on January 13, 2023, of the facility's "Wilkes Barre General Hospital Medical Staff Rules And Regulations," dated May 2021, revealed  "These Rules and Regulations are adopted in connection with the Medical Staff Bylaws and made a part thereof. The definitions and terminologies of the bylaws also apply to the Rules and Regulations and proceedings hereunder.  ... Article VI Emergency Medical Screening. Treatment. Transfer and On-Call Roster Policy  ... 6.2 Consultations, Referrals and Emergency Department Call 6.2(a) When the Emergency Department Physician determines that a consultation or specialized treatment beyond the capability of the Emergency Department Physician is needed, the patient shall be permitted to request the services of a specific private physician. This request will be documented in the patient's medical record. The Emergency Department Physician will utilize the rotation call list as set forth in this Section 6.2 if the patient does not have a private Physician who is available and qualified to provide the necessary services.  ... 6.2(d) The rotation call list, containing the names and phone numbers of the on-call physicians shall be posted in the Emergency Department. In the event that the patient does not have a private physician, the private physician refuses the patient's request to come to the Emergency Department, or the physician cannot be contacted within twenty (20) minutes of the initial request, the rotation call list shall be used to select a private physician to provide the necessary consultation or treatment for the patient. A physician who has been called from the rotation list may not refuse to respond. The Emergency Department physician's determination shall control whether the on-call physician is required to come in to personally assess the patient.  ... 6.2(e)The physician called from the rotation schedule shall be held responsible for the care of a patient until the problem prompting the patient's assignment to that physician is satisfactorily resolved or stabilized to permit disposition of the patient. This responsibility may include follow-up care for the referred patient in the physician's office. If, after examining the patient, the physician who is consulted or is called from the rotation schedule feels that a consultation with another specialist is indicated, it will be the responsibility of the Emergency Room provider to arrange for the additional consultations. 6.2(f) All members of the Active Staff shall participate in the on-call back up to the Emergency Department as required by the Board, upon recommendations of the MEC.  ... The MEC and the Board shall retain ultimate authority for making determinations regarding call requirements based upon the needs of the Hospital and its patients, and upon the Hospital's obligation to ensure that the services regularly available to its Hospital patients are available to the Emergency Department. In the event any physician or specialty represented on the Active Staff is excused from call, the MEC and the Board shall document the reasons, and shall ensure that such decision does not negatively impact upon the Hospital's ability to fulfill its obligations as outlined above. Physicians called are required to respond to Emergency Department call by telephone within ten (10) minutes. If requested to come in, they are required to do so within twenty (20) minutes after responding by telephone. Anesthesiologists and CRNAs are required to arrive within twenty (20) minutes of initial contact. 6.2(g) The system for providing on-call coverage, including specification of which specialties shall cover call and the minimum obligations therefore, shall be approved by the Board of Trustees and documented in writing.  ..."Review on January 13, 2023, of the facility's cardiothoracic physician on-call schedule for the ED for December 2022 revealed for December 9, 2022, December 10, 2022, December 11, 2022, December 27, 2022, December 28, 2022, December 29, 2022, December 30, 2022, and December 31, 2022, there was no cardiothoracic surgeon on call for the facility's ED. Continued review revealed January 1, 2023, January 2, 2023, January 12, 2023 and January 13, 2023, there was no cardiothoracic on call for the ED.Interview on January 13, 2023, with EMP1, at approximately 10:00 AM confirmed the facility's cardiothoracic physician on-call schedule for the ED for December 2022 revealed for December 9, 2022, December 10, 2022, December 11, 2022, December 27, 2022, December 28, 2022, December 29, 2022, December 30, 2022, and December 31, 2022, there was no cardiothoracic surgeon on call for the facility's ED. EMP1 also confirmed for January 1, 2023, January 2, 2023, January 12, 2023 and January 13, 2023, there was also no cardiothoracic on call for the ED.Review on January 13, 2022, of the facility's Interventional Radiology (IR) physician on-call schedules for December 2022, revealed for December 1, 2022, December 2, 2022, December 3, 2022, December 4, 2022, December 12, 2022, December 13, 2022, December 15, 2022, December 23, 2022, December 24, 2022, December 25, 2022, December 26, 2022, December 31, 2022, there was no IR physician on call for the facility's ED. Continued review revealed for January 1, 2023, January 2, 2023, January 3, 2023, January 5, 2023, January 6, 2023, January 7, 2023, and January 8, 2023, there was no IR physician on call for the ED.Interview on January 13, 2023, with EMP1, at approximately 10:10 AM confirmed the facility's Interventional Radiology (IR) physician on-call schedules for December 2022, revealed for December 1, 2022, December 2, 2022, December 3, 2022, December 4, 2022, December 12, 2022, December 13, 2022, December 15, 2022, December 23, 2022, December 24, 2022, December 25, 2022, December 26, 2022, December 31, 2022, there was no IR physician on call for the facility's ED. EMP1 confirmed for January 1, 2023, January 2, 2023, January 3, 2023, January 5, 2023, January 6, 2023, January 7, 2023, and January 8, 2023, there was no IR physician on call for the ED.Review on January 13, 2023, of the facility's Vascular Surgery on-call schedules for December 2022, revealed for December 23, 2022, and December 27, 2022, there was no vascular surgeon on call for the facility's ED. Continued review revealed for January 1, 2023, January 2, 2023, January 5, 2023, January 7, 2023, and January 8, 2023, there was no vascular surgeon on call for the ED. Interview on January 13, 2023, with EMP1, at approximately 11:15 AM confirmed the facility's Vascular Surgery on-call schedules for December 2022, revealed for December 23, 2022, and December 27, 2022, there was no vascular surgeon on call for the facility's ED. EMP1 confirmed for January 1, 2023, January 2, 2023, January 5, 2023, January 7, 2023, and January 8, 2023, there was no vascular surgeon on call for the ED. Plan of Correction - To be completed: 04/04/2023Wilkes-Barre General Hospital's administration reviewed the current community demand for Emergency Services and the current supply of employed, contracted and temporary medical staff available with the Medical Executive Committee and Board of Trustees during their February meetings.Wilkes-Barre General Hospital  is working to create a community call agreement with Regional Hospital of Scranton for interventional radiology coverage.  The coverage is targeted to begin no later than April 4, 2023.The facility has issued notice of termination of ED on-call vascular surgery services with an effective date of April 4, 2023.  Communication of this change to all applicable hospital staff will be completed no later than March 1, 2023.  All future cases will be referred to the general surgeon on call or transferred in compliance with the Medical Staff Bylaws.The facility will provide a second cardiac surgeon to facilitate on-call services to Wilkes-Barre General Hospital beginning April 4, 2023.  Any patient needing cardiac surgery care until the second surgeon is in place will be stabilized and transferred in compliance with the Medical Staff Bylaws. The Chief Executive Officer will continue to closely monitor the ED on call schedule for gaps in cardiac surgery and interventional radiology on a monthly basis.  Any gaps in ED on-call interventional radiology or cardiac surgery coverage will be communicated to the Medical Executive Committee and Board of Trustees monthly.  All appropriate reports to the PA-PSRS system in the form of infrastructure failures will be submitted timely. 117.26 (b)(1-4) LICENSURE PHYSICIAN ON-CALL SCHEDULE: 117.26 (b) Acceptable methods of providing
